case.title: Should AI assistants receive on-air credit for investigative packages?
case.context: A national newsroom wants to credit its AI summarization system alongside reporters on televised investigations.
case.sideA: The reporters' guild argues contractual byline language requires human credit unless renegotiated.
case.sideB: Studio leadership claims acknowledging AI tooling builds transparency and audience trust.

transcript.text: Our contract binds credits to human journalists; adding software without bargaining weakens accountability.
Viewers deserve to know when automation helped surface leads—it's disclosure, not theft.
Transparency can happen in footnotes; credit implies authorship and erodes reporter leverage.
Audiences already assume AI is involved; naming it keeps trust intact while honoring innovation.

cases.summary: Panel sided with the reporters' guild, finding the studio must negotiate before crediting AI systems on investigative packages.

case.title: Can the city enforce an overnight e-bike delivery curfew?
case.context: City officials propose a midnight-to-6am e-bike ban after a spike in late-night collisions.
case.sideA: Delivery platforms argue the curfew unfairly cuts income for riders who rely on overnight demand.
case.sideB: The transportation department cites emergency room data and wants a temporary cooling-off period.

transcript.text: Riders already passed safety courses; the city should target reckless actors, not gut incomes.
ER admissions tripled after midnight; a short pause gives space to add lighting and training.
Platforms offered to co-fund reflective gear—work with them rather than impose a blanket ban.
A 90-day pilot with weekly data releases balances livelihoods with immediate public safety.

cases.summary: Majority let the curfew pilot proceed, requiring the city to publish weekly data on delivery delays during the 90-day trial.
